criteria: Ability to accurately estimate a population mean or proportion from sample survey data.
Competence in developing a margin of error using simulation models for random sampling.
Understanding of the limitations and assumptions in using sample data to make inferences about a population.
descriptions: No attempt to estimate the population mean or proportion.
Attempts to estimate, but the method used is inappropriate or contains significant errors.
Estimates the population mean or proportion with some errors in calculation or application of the method.
Estimates the population mean or proportion reasonably well, with only minor errors.
Accurately estimates the population mean or proportion from the sample data using appropriate methods.
Accurately estimates the population mean or proportion and justifies the choice of method with clear reasoning.
No attempt to develop a margin of error.
Attempts to develop a margin of error, but the simulation model is inappropriate or poorly executed.
Develops a margin of error using simulation, but there are errors in the model or interpretation of results.
Develops a reasonable margin of error using simulation, with only minor flaws in the model or interpretation.
Effectively develops a margin of error using appropriate simulation models for random sampling.
Develops a margin of error with a sophisticated simulation model and clearly explains the implications of the margin of error in context.
Shows no awareness of the limitations or assumptions involved in making inferences.
Demonstrates limited understanding of the limitations and assumptions.
Acknowledges some limitations and assumptions, but does not fully explain their impact.
Understands and explains most of the important limitations and assumptions.
Clearly articulates the key limitations and assumptions and how they affect the reliability of the inferences.
Provides a comprehensive analysis of the limitations and assumptions, including strategies to mitigate their impact on the validity of the conclusions.
